The annual chore of rushing,
a long siege for both freshmen
and fraternity men, will come
to a close tomorrow when the
freshmen submit their fraternity
bids from 9-11 A.M. in Levering
Hall. After a long three and
one half weeks of rushing, serious contemplation of studies can
now be undertaken by all and
time-wasting can become an
individual matter rather than a
regimented one.
Needless to say the rushing
period has, had its high and low
points, but Don Steiner, President of the IFC, feels that in
general "the rushing has been
conducted very well." Most upperclassmen seemed to agree
that this years' schedule was
the best in a long time.

rushing, President Steiner said
that he would like to "make the
rush rules more specific by defining them in certain areas."

rules of rushing are written down
and they are three years old.

to see more rules and penalities
decided beforehand by all the
fraternities so that the IFC
would have added authority
during the rushing period.

weaknesses he felt existed in
this year's rush schedule, Steiner

replied, "The orientation was
the basic failing of this year's
rush season, and, more specifically, the failure of the IFC smoker, which was designed to get
the rushees started on the right
foot."

an IFC assembly similar to this
year's Honor Commission assembly.

second semester rushing, he said •

better "to get rushing out of

it for several months.

European students have for centuries been a prime
political force. 'Fheir avid interest in national and international affairs has gained for those students and universities a wide respect and admiration from their countrymen. The striking difference in attitude toward the
European student Ps enviously clear to an American
student travelling briefly in Europe. American students,
by contrast, enjoy little but contempt from informed
opinion in the United States and abroad. The American
student population, we contend, derives this contempt
from its own apathetic attitude toward issues of real
importance.
It's sheer nonsense to contend that a university
student council is not competent to give opinions on
national and international issues. It's simply an evasion
of the rather difficult responsibility of keeping one's self
informed adequately. It is frightening to think that a
student, living in today's world of dynamic change, could
possibly abstain from voting on the discrimination issue
on the grounds that he doesn't know enough about racial
problems. But that's just what Sophomore representative
George Elder did.

that students can and should have opinions and attitudes

hauntingly intense style, ably
supplemented by his two assistants: Kanai Dutta on the tabla,

An evenings entertainment at
Shriver Hall may often turn out
to be very rewarding. Such was
the case at last Sunday's concert sppnsored by the YMCA
and the Cosmopolitan Club featuring Ravi Shankar and his
amazing sitar. However, I wish
to caution the reader that this
article is not meant as a review
or a critique. After all, it is impossible to criticize that which
is imperfectly understood, and
this party definitely does not understand Indian Music.
Nonetheless, lack of understanding did not prevent the audience from being wholeheartedly enthusiastic, so obvious was
Mr. Shankar's interpretive genius, and refined virtuosity. Little
more can be said about India's
Renaissance man, because words
Will never give him his proper
due.

Nor can much be said about
the music he and his company
played, except 'that it was
strange, exotic and interesting.
But "interesting" is not the right
word; anyone in the Shriver audience would have willingly substituted the word "fascinating"
in contrast to such a compromise
as "interesting". It was fascinating as played by Shankar. Anyone who has the pleasure to be
introduced to Indian music by
such an artist can hardly
ignore it.
After a year of applied study
and constant exposure to the
same, perhaps we can venture to
criticize Mr. Shankar's performance. Now we can only sit back
and marvel at the sitarist's
hauntingly intense style, ably
supplemented by his two assistants: Kanai Dutta on the tabla,
and N. C. Mullick on the tamboura.

who turned themselves in before
October twentieth, he replied
that they would receive an expression of his appreciation for
their compliance, though somewhat belated, with the rule.
